content: The Transition toward Excellence, Achievement, and Mobility through Empowerment Act of 2011, also known as the TEAM-Empowerment Act of 2011, includes a short title and table of contents. The Act outlines individualized transition plans and transition planning services administrative units. Congress finds that inclusive education, work experience, career exploration, paid work experience, self-determination, flexibility in funding, and additional training for agency officials lead to better outcomes for individuals with significant disabilities during their transition into adulthood. The Act aims to create a holistic system for successful transition of youth with significant disabilities into adulthood, focusing on high expectations, equality of opportunity, self-determination, post-secondary options leading to competitive employment, and long-term community integration. Additional training is required for agency officials to address individual transition needs effectively. Promote innovative strategies for academic, professional, and social inclusion, solidify long-term supports for community integration, define and coordinate transition services for youth with disabilities, eliminate barriers for collaboration among stakeholders to improve transition opportunities. SEC. 3. INDIVIDUALIZED TRANSITION PLANS; TRANSITION PLANNING AND SERVICES ADMINISTRATIVE UNITS. Title I of the Developmental Disabilities Assistance and Bill of Rights Act of 2000 is amended by adding a new section called "Subtitle F--Adult Transition System" with defined terms. The curr_chunk defines terms related to asset development, individualized education programs, and integrated employment for individuals with disabilities. The curr_chunk defines terms related to asset development, individualized education programs, and integrated employment for individuals with disabilities. It includes definitions such as 'ITP' for individual transition plans, 'local educational agency,' 'secondary school,' and 'State intellectual and developmental disabilities agency.' Key details include the setting for employees with disabilities to interact with nondisabled co-workers, opportunities for advancement, and engagement in full-time employment. The curr_chunk defines terms related to transition services for students with disabilities, including the role of the State disabilities agency and the definition of transition services as activities promoting movement from school to post-school activities. The coordinated set of activities for transition services for students with disabilities includes instruction, community experiences, career preparation, work-based learning, youth development, self-advocacy training, family involvement, and daily living skills. Facility-based employment settings like sheltered workshops are not included. The coordinated set of activities for transition services for students with disabilities includes instruction, community experiences, career preparation, work-based learning, youth development, self-advocacy training, family involvement, and acquisition of daily living skills. This does not include facility-based employment settings like sheltered workshops. The activities should lead to outcomes such as post-secondary education, long-term integrated employment, asset development, independent living, and community participation. The Secretary will make grants to States for activities required under this subtitle, allocating payments based on the number of individuals to be served. Individualized transition plans are also required. Each State receiving assistance under this subtitle must develop an individual transition plan for individuals with developmental disabilities transitioning into adulthood. The plan must coordinate transition services for integrated employment, postsecondary education, independent living, and community engagement. The plan should be formulated within 30 days of the individual exiting secondary school, applicable until the individual turns 26, and reviewed annually. The individual transition plan for individuals with developmental disabilities must be developed by each State within 30 days of exiting secondary school, applicable until age 26, and reviewed annually. The plan is developed during in-person meetings led by the State's intellectual and developmental disabilities agency, involving key stakeholders such as the individual, family, transition broker, vocational rehabilitation agency, and relevant service providers. An ITP (Individual Transition Plan) is developed for individuals with developmental disabilities within 30 days of exiting secondary school, lasting until age 26 and reviewed annually. The plan includes strategies for postsecondary educational experiences, career preparation, work-based learning, development, leadership, connecting activities, and family involvement. It aims to advance economic self-sufficiency with specific asset development goals and tools. The Individual Transition Plan (ITP) for individuals with developmental disabilities includes strategies for postsecondary education, career preparation, work-based learning, leadership development, and family involvement. It aims to advance economic self-sufficiency through specific asset development goals and tools such as tax benefits, work incentives, savings plans, education financing, and budget management strategies. The Individual Transition Plan (ITP) for individuals with developmental disabilities includes strategies for postsecondary education, career preparation, work-based learning, leadership development, and family involvement. It aims to advance economic self-sufficiency through specific asset development goals and tools such as tax benefits, work incentives, savings plans, education financing, and budget management strategies. SEC. 174. TRANSITION PLANNING AND SERVICES ADMINISTRATIVE UNIT. Each State receiving assistance under this subtitle must establish a Transition Planning and Services (TPS) administrative unit within the State intellectual and developmental disabilities agency. The primary focus of the TPS unit is to help individuals with developmental disabilities transition from the secondary school system into adulthood by developing and implementing Individual Transition Plans (ITPs) with the assistance of transition brokers. Transition brokers in the TPS administrative unit facilitate coordination among State agencies, provide assistance to individuals with developmental disabilities in navigating support services, and must possess expertise in various relevant areas. Transition brokers in the TPS administrative unit must have expertise in benefits planning, transition services, employment, workforce development, vocational rehabilitation, asset development, self-sufficiency tools, self-direction, and person-centered planning. The TPS administrative unit assigns transition brokers to individuals based on their selection and state agency approval. They provide training on self-advocacy, self-determination skills, and peer mentoring to improve advocacy abilities. Additionally, they offer information and resources to individuals with developmental disabilities and their families. The TPS administrative unit provides information on Federal and State services, supports, and regulations to individuals with developmental disabilities and their families. The State intellectual and developmental disabilities agency facilitates collaboration among key State agencies to improve services for individuals transitioning into adulthood. The Secretary is required to submit an annual report to Congress evaluating the implementation and effectiveness of the subtitle, including the number of individuals with Individual Transition Plans (ITPs) developed, progress made in implementing ITP objectives, and demographic information of individuals with ITPs. $50,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2012 to 2016 to carry out this subtitle.
